title: Online Social Studies Course Design Applying Digital Bloom's Taxonomy

context.prior_knowledge: Basic digital literacy and foundational understanding of Bloom’s Taxonomy
context.additional_context: Designing social studies curricula for non-degree-seeking adult learners in a smartphone-centric limited-technology environment.

learning_goals: The six levels of Digital Bloom’s Taxonomy (Remembering-Understanding-Applying-Analyzing-Evaluating-Creating) can be applied to online learning activities.

Learners design a 3-tier hierarchical learning module (foundational-applied-advanced) using smartphone-based digital tools (quizzes, discussion boards, collaborative documents) in an LMS environment, achieving an average of 4 or higher on a 5-point rubric through peer evaluation.

Learners develop 5 multiple-choice, 3 short-answer, and 2 case-analysis questions per level (1–3) aligned with the digital Bloom’s taxonomy (remembering, understanding, applying, analyzing, evaluating, creating) for three social studies units (history, politics, economics), achieving ≥80% validity in peer review.

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
